Class ec.time.Clock 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.time.Clock
public class Clock
extends Object
This is a layer on top of the Timer stuff. A Clock has an essentially similar interface to Timer, except that it has a settable resolution, and may be started and stopped and have its time changed at will. BUG--don't use this class yet. It works (arguably), but is way inefficient. It does a callback per tick, which can be pretty bad if your resolution is in the low-msec range. If you want to use the class let me (danfuzz) know.

Clock(long, int)
Create a Clock which uses a private Timer for its actual timing needs.
Clock(Timer, long, int)
Create a Clock which uses the given timer for its actual timing needs.

getTime()
Get the current time of this Clock.
setAbsoluteCallback(Runnable, long)
Set a callback to occur at the given absolute time.
setAbsoluteRepeatCallback(Runnable, long)
Set a repeating callback to occur at the rate of one per the given number of ticks.
setRelativeCallback(Runnable, long)
Set a callback to occur the given number of ticks from now.
setRelativeRepeatCallback(Runnable, long)
Set a repeating callback to occur at the rate of one per the given number of ticks.
setTime(long)
Set the time of this Clock.
start()
Start up the clock.
stop()
Stop the clock.

Clock 
 public Clock(Timer theTimer,
              long theResMillis,
              int theResNanos)
Create a Clock which uses the given timer for its actual timing needs. The given resolution is the amount of time between ticks. The Clock starts out stopped and at time 0.

Parameters:
theTimer - the Timer to use
theResMillis - the msec of the resolution
theResNanos - the nanosec of the resolution
Clock 
 public Clock(long theResMillis,
              int theResNanos)
Create a Clock which uses a private Timer for its actual timing needs. Note that it is reccommended that one use the constructor which takes a timer, so that multiple Clocks may share the heavier-weight Timer.

Parameters:
theResMillis - the msec of the resolution
theResNanos - the nanosec of the resolution

setTime 
 public void setTime(long theTime)
Set the time of this Clock.

Parameters:
theTime - the new time of the clock
getTime 
 public long getTime()
Get the current time of this Clock.

Returns:
the current time of the clock
start 
 public void start()
Start up the clock.

stop 
 public void stop()
Stop the clock.

setRelativeCallback 
 public TimerCallback setRelativeCallback(Runnable runnable,
                                          long ticks)
Set a callback to occur the given number of ticks from now. The callback runs in the same thread used for callbacks by the timer that this Clock uses.

Parameters:
runnable - the Runnable to run
ticks - the number of ticks before the callback occurs
Returns:
the callback object to use for cancellation
setAbsoluteCallback 
 public TimerCallback setAbsoluteCallback(Runnable runnable,
                                          long time)
Set a callback to occur at the given absolute time. The callback runs in the same thread used for callbacks by the timer that this Clock uses.

Parameters:
runnable - the Runnable to run
time - the time to run the callback at
Returns:
the callback object to use for cancellation
setAbsoluteRepeatCallback 
 public TimerCallback setAbsoluteRepeatCallback(Runnable runnable,
                                                long ticks)
Set a repeating callback to occur at the rate of one per the given number of ticks. It fires at absolute intervals, that is, successive calls are made at last time + ticks.

Parameters:
runnable - the Runnable to run
ticks - the number of ticks between callbacks
Returns:
the callback object to use for cancellation
setRelativeRepeatCallback 
 public TimerCallback setRelativeRepeatCallback(Runnable runnable,
                                                long ticks)
Set a repeating callback to occur at the rate of one per the given number of ticks. It fires at relative intervals, that is, successive calls are made at now + ticks.

Parameters:
runnable - the Runnable to run
ticks - the number of ticks between callbacks
Returns:
the callback object to use for cancellation
